conversation.content: True or False? If every proper subsequence of ($x_n$) converges, then ($x_n$) converges as well.

False. A sequence can have every proper subsequence converging (for example, all subsequences except the sequence itself), but the sequence itself may not converge if it oscillates or does not approach a single limit.
That answer is wrong. Fix it.

True. If every proper subsequence of \((x_n)\) converges, they must all converge to the same limit; otherwise, there would be subsequences converging to different limits. Hence, the original sequence \((x_n)\) converges to that common limit.

False. Consider a sequence that does not converge but every proper subsequence converges. For example, the sequence defined by \(x_n = (-1)^n\) does not converge, but any proper subsequence that excludes infinitely many terms converges (e.g., constant subsequences). Thus, the original sequence need not converge even if every proper subsequence does.

True. If every proper subsequence of \((x_n)\) converges, then all these subsequences must converge to the same limit; otherwise, there would be at least two subsequences converging to different limits. This implies the original sequence \((x_n)\) converges to that common limit.

False. A proper subsequence is any subsequence that is not the entire sequence. If every proper subsequence converges, it does not guarantee the original sequence converges. For example, consider a constant sequence except for one term that diverges; all proper subsequences (excluding that term) converge, but the full sequence does not.
